This is Lever Weekly, a recap of our work from the past week. If you only read one email from us all week, this should be it.

Along with a breakdown of our reporting, podcasts, and live events for all subscribers, we are providing paid subscribers with an original column. In this week‚Äôs piece, David Sirota shows how Democrats‚Äô effusive celebration of a GOP-sculpted debt deal clarifies exactly what they believe is a victory, and for whom (hint: It ain‚Äôt the working class).

üëá Scroll down below our weekly recap for this week‚Äôs column, exclusively for our paid subscribers.

This is Lever Weekly, a recap of our work from the past week. If you only read one email from us all week, this should be it.

Along with a breakdown of our reporting, podcasts, and live events for all subscribers, we provide paid subscribers with an exclusive original column. In this week‚Äôs piece, David Sirota shows how Democrats‚Äô effusive celebration of a GOP-sculpted debt deal clarifies exactly what they believe is a victory, and for whom (hint: It ain‚Äôt the working class).

üëá Following is an excerpt of our subscriber-only column, and below that is a recap of all of our other work from the week.

This Is What Biden Says Is A ‚ÄúBig Win‚Äù

By David Sirota

President Biden had his ‚Äúmission accomplished‚Äù moment this week when his White House took to social media to tout this week‚Äôs debt ceiling deal as a ‚Äúmajor Biden administration victory.‚Äù

The endzone football spike was an abrupt shift from Democrats previously depicting the debt ceiling deal‚Äôs spending cuts, Pentagon budget increases, and fossil fuel giveaways as an unfortunate-but-unavoidable compromise that at least prevented a catastrophic default.

Now, we‚Äôre asked by Democrats and their media machine to believe that this wasn‚Äôt a...

children.text: Stuff The Lever Reported This Week:
Debt Deal Gives Fossil Fuel Lobby A Legal Shield
‚Äî
Industry donations flowed to key Dem senators just before a major pipeline approval was slipped into the debt ceiling bill.
The Dark Money Behind Kansas‚Äô Misleading Anti-Abortion Campaign
‚Äî
Tax records show how Leonard Leo‚Äôs $1.6 billion dark money network is quietly working to eliminate state abortion protections.
Adam McKay: 1.5C Is Terrifying But There Is Something We Haven‚Äôt Tried
‚Äî

Adam McKay is a film director and producer recently founded Yellow Dot Studios, a media company to fight climate disinformation. Today, he offers a dose of outrage and imagination in the face of dire climate warnings.
YOU LOVE TO SEE IT: Minnesota Is High On Progress
‚Äî
Also, a wealth tax yields crazy high returns, an abandoned oil tanker in Yemen will finally be rescued, a New York pizzeria gets a union, noncompetes take a hit, and more.
Stuff To Watch Or Listen To:
LEVER TIME: Social Media Is Killing Our Kids ‚Äî Sen. Chris Murphy Has a Plan
‚Äî
David speaks with U.S. Sen. Chris Murphy about social media‚Äôs harmful effects on kids, and the debt ceiling deal.
MOVIES VS. CAPITALISM: The Succession Finale (w/ David Sirota)
‚Äî
Rivka and Frank discuss the series finale of HBO‚Äôs
Succession
LEVER TIME PREMIUM: No Politics But Class Politics
‚Äî
In an exclusive for paid subscribers, David Sirota sits down with political theorist Adolph Reed Jr. to discuss his new book.
LEVER LIVE: Q&A With Rep. Ro Khanna On House Debt Vote
‚Äî
If you missed our paid subscriber-only live event this week, where U.S. Rep. Ro Khanna took questions about the debt ceiling deal,
you can watch a replay on YouTube
Thank You To Our Newest Lever Leaders:

Lever Leaders provide us with our highest level of support and score additional perks in return.  Each week, we highlight folks who‚Äôve taken that step, and the reasons they say they‚Äôve done so, if they wish to share.
Barbara D:
‚ÄúMy parents were survivors of the Great Depression and raised my sister and me to expect better lives (which we had) but here we are again on a precipice.‚Äù
Christian Ludwig

This Is What Biden Says Is A ‚ÄúBig Win‚Äù
By David Sirota
President
Biden
had his ‚Äúmission accomplished‚Äù moment this week when his White House
took to social media
to tout this week‚Äôs debt ceiling deal as a ‚Äúmajor Biden administration victory.‚Äù

The endzone football spike was an abrupt shift from Democrats previously depicting the debt ceiling deal‚Äôs spending cuts, Pentagon budget increases, and fossil fuel giveaways as an unfortunate-but-unavoidable compromise that at least prevented a catastrophic default.
Now, we‚Äôre asked by Democrats and their
media machine

to believe that this wasn‚Äôt a reluctant rearguard defensive action, it was instead a triumph ‚Äî Biden‚Äôs very own LBJ-esque display of successful arm-twisting and masterful negotiation that delivered a ‚Äúbig win,‚Äù in the president‚Äôs own words, which he amplified in
his first Oval Office address
This tonal change is as much a celebration as it is an admission ‚Äî one providing a rare moment of honesty and clarity.
It tells us that this deal is exactly what Democrats always wanted.
It also tells us precisely what Democratic leaders believe is a win ‚Äî and for whom they want to secure such victories.

children.calloutText: Follow us on Apple News and Google News to make sure you see our stories first, and to help make sure others see our breaking news as well.

children.text: To The Victors Go The Spoils
In this deal, big corporations, private equity moguls, and the affluent class all scored wins when both parties prevented the bill from including tax reforms, such as
closing tax loopholes
and repealing high-income tax cuts. This, even though
data
show that recent tax cuts were primarily responsible for growth in the debt‚Äôs proportional size.
The rich also got a big victory in the bill‚Äôs provisions
gutting funding
for tax enforcement.
Defense contracting industry donors
got their own win when both parties agreed to boost the Pentagon‚Äôs annual budget to
nearly $900 billion
‚Äî a
record size
. At the same time the legislation implements a dark-money-funded
conservative group‚Äôs initiative
designed to make it more difficult for the poorest people to
access food stamps
Executives at private student lending companies ‚Äî which have been
furiously lobbying
lawmakers ‚Äî won when both parties used the deal to end a moratorium on student debt payments for federal borrowers. One of the largest lenders‚Äô stock price
began rising
as the deal neared completion.
And as the
climate emergency worsens
, fossil fuel industry donors grabbed
yet another
win
in the form of a
massive gas pipeline
that will not only be expedited, but also exempted from any court challenge ‚Äî a
judicial shield
that Democrats have never tried to extend to abortion rights, civil rights or voting rights.
Meanwhile, the deal omits any provisions to speed up the construction of transmission lines for clean energy projects, and may actually make that kind of permitting reform
more difficult in the future

children.calloutText: Follow us on YouTube to see all of our latest video reports and filmed podcast segments.

children.text: ‚ÄúIt Takes Too Much Time‚Äù

It‚Äôs obvious that Republicans always wanted this outcome. They proudly and honestly shout their support for this agenda from the floors of both congressional chambers. Democrats usually do something more deceptive ‚Äî they pretend they love the progressive agenda, hate what‚Äôs happening, and then vote for it anyway.

But with much of the American Left crushed into fine dust and a non-factor in Washington, the party‚Äôs leaders are no longer bothering with pretense. More often than not, they are letting the mask drop and doing what they did this time around.
The early tell came in the lame duck session of Congress, when Democrats could have passed a clean debt ceiling increase via
reconciliation

, but chose not to. Knowing the left has little deterrent power and knowing how few liberals care about anything other than watching MSNBC, party leaders didn‚Äôt even feel the need to provide the public with a legitimate reason for inaction. Senate Majority Whip Dick Durbin just came right out and
said
he and his colleagues didn‚Äôt feel like making space on the congressional calendar to do it.
‚ÄúThat would not be done this year by reconciliation ‚Äî it takes too much time,‚Äù Durbin
said
in November, despite pleading to do so from
Sen. Bernie Sanders
(I-Vt.) and
Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen
among others. ‚ÄúWe have three weeks and there is too much else on the agenda.‚Äù
If by that point you didn‚Äôt realize this was all a
Washington Generals/Harlem Globetrotters game
with a predetermined outcome, Biden made it explicit when the debt ceiling came back up last month.
Rather than taking a stand, he
stomped on

Democratic lawmakers calling for him to use the constitution‚Äôs 14th amendment to bypass Republicans‚Äô predictable hostage game. Knowing liberals would obediently accept the ‚Äúdon‚Äôt make the perfect the enemy of the good‚Äù canard, Biden pretended he had no power to do anything other than bow to GOP demands, even when
that was patently false
Then as soon as the monstrous package of budget cuts and fossil fuel giveaways was cobbled together,
Politico
reported that Biden‚Äôs ‚Äúteam went into overdrive,‚Äù placing ‚Äúover 100 one-on-one calls with House Democrats‚Äù and holding ‚Äúwonky virtual meetings over the negotiation details.‚Äù
The pressure was wildly successful ‚Äî not only did the debt deal pass by wide margins in
both
chambers
, Senate Democrats also joined Republicans in
killing
an amendment to strip the pipeline out of the legislation. It was the kind of blitzkrieg ‚Äî
flaunted on social media

by the White House‚Äôs deputy press secretary ‚Äî that has never been deployed by Biden to enact policies that would help millions of Americans, like his promised $15 minimum wage or a public health insurance option, both of which remain absolutely nowhere in the political conversation.
‚ÄúPeople Who Say They Love You Also F*ck You‚Äù
And so now here we are with a deal that House Speaker Kevin McCarthy is celebrating ‚Äî a deal that the
Republican-led
Congressional Budget Office
desperately tried to sugarcoat
, but that a major Democratic Party-aligned budget think tank
admits
will ‚Äúincrease hunger and poverty‚Äù and ‚Äúput hundreds of thousands of older adults aged 50-54 at risk of losing food assistance.‚Äù

Perhaps such a bitter pill could be more easily ramrodded down America‚Äôs gagging throat if most Democrats were at least pretending that this was the best they could do and at least performatively faking a bit of sadness about the agreement‚Äôs horrors. But other than a
handful
of lawmakers admitting the brutal truth about what happened, it‚Äôs been the opposite.
Far from being ashamed of the outcome, the Democratic White House is
declaring
this ‚Äúa big win for our economy and the American people,‚Äù all while MSNBC
lauds
progressive lawmakers not for standing up to the atrocity, but for loyally falling in line and providing votes to make it a reality.
In light of this, one might see Democrats in the same way
Succession
‚Äôs Logan Roy viewed his bumbling children ‚Äî as ‚Äú
not serious people.
‚Äù But these Washington politicians are deadly serious.
For decades, Biden has made
explicitly clear
just how serious he is about forging alliances with Republicans to freeze or cut government spending. He literally
delivered
speeches
on the Senate floor bragging about how many times he‚Äôs tried to do it.

His dream now coming true makes clear how serious he and his party‚Äôs congressional caucus are about simultaneously delivering for their big donors while insisting with a straight face that they really support a progressive agenda that would challenge those donors‚Äô wealth and power.
The accurate conclusion about Democratic leaders, then, is the axiom
uttered
by Logan‚Äôs dejected son Kendall: ‚ÄúPeople who say they love you also f*ck you.‚Äù

Until rank-and-file Democratic voters admit that painful truth about their party bosses ‚Äî and are willing to challenge them and their ethos in primary elections ‚Äî Biden will remain the same austerian he‚Äôs always been, and Democratic politicians will continue allying with Republicans for ‚Äúbig wins‚Äù that protect the rich, pulverize the working class and destroy the livable climate.
